key_points: Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, confirmed Meghan and Harry were not legally married before their public ceremony.
Meghan Markle revealed in an interview with Oprah Winfrey that they had a private exchange of vows three days before their wedding.
The private ceremony did not have witnesses, leading to speculation it was not legally binding.
Welby clarified he signed the legal document on the day of their public wedding, May 19, 2018.
Signing a false wedding certificate would have been a serious criminal offense, according to Welby.
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle officially married at St. George's Chapel in Windsor.
The couple stepped back from royal duties in January of the previous year.
In their interview with Oprah, they discussed racism within the royal family and Meghan's mental health struggles.
One of the major revelations was concerns within the royal family about the skin color of their unborn child, Archie.
The interview allowed Harry and Meghan to speak more freely about their experiences in the royal family.
